title: Greubel Forsey’s Hand Made 1 Takes Handcrafted To Extremes
text:
To complete the first watch, Greubel Forsey had to produce more than 800 components.

Text size

Greubel Forsey’s newly unveiled Hand Made 1 is a testament to the brand’s longstanding commitment to preserving watchmaking’s traditional skills and techniques.

The first Hand Made 1 required 6,000 hours (equal to three years of man hours) to produce, with 95% of the watch—including the hairspring—made using only hand-operated tools.

“We are actually very clear about what we didn’t hand make: the spring bars for the strap, the sapphire crystals, the case gaskets, the jewels, and the mainspring,” says co-founder Stephen Forsey during a conversation in Boston. “Otherwise, even the screws themselves are handmade, piece by piece, individually on a precision toolmaker’s lathe.”

Producing a single screw in this manner requires as many as 12 operations and eight hours. Furthermore, to complete the first watch, they had to produce more than 800 components to yield the necessary 308 parts that met the brand’s uncompromising standards.

Because the 43.5mm white gold piece is unique, Greubel Forsey has yet to set a price, but acknowledges that it will likely be well over $500,000. The brand plans to produce two or three pieces per year.

The roots of the Hand Made 1 stretch all the way back to Forsey’s early days in London when he made his own parts to restore antique watches. Meanwhile, Robert Greubel started out making prototypes. Both had experience in taking raw pieces of metal and fashioning them into watch components using age-old methods.

When they started working together, they recognized the potential of utilizing cutting-edge CNC technology that was sweeping the industry to focus on the exquisite hand-finishing skills for which they are revered.

“By using CNC machines, or numerical control machines, to make raw components, we could do more on the hand finishing,” Forsey says. “And we could also develop the innovative side of Greubel Forsey, because we had a lot of mechanisms we wanted to develop.”

In the ensuing years, the partners lamented the loss of traditional watchmaking skills as automated machines increasingly took over from human hands. Their response was to found the Time Aeon Foundation in 2005 in partnership with independent watchmakers Philippe Dufour, Vianney Halter, and Kari Voutilainen.

Greubel Forsey's Hand Made 1. Greubel Forsey

With a mission to preserve the ancient techniques that were becoming extinct, Time Aeon established the Naissance d’une Montre (Birth of a Watch) project. They tapped Michel Boulanger, a watchmaking teacher in Paris, to build a tourbillon watch under the masters’ tutelage entirely by hand with the help of historical manual machinery. He would then pass on his acquired knowledge and skills to future generations to keep them alive.

The project kicked off in 2009, and the prototype was unveiled in 2015 with 10 additional pieces planned and quickly reserved by collectors. In May 2016, the prototype watch sold at Christie’s Hong Kong for US$1.46 million, raising funds for future Naissance d’une Montre endeavors.

“With Time Aeon Foundation, we hoped people would support at least training a minimum number of watchmakers and skill people each year with these traditional techniques,” Forsey says, acknowledging the challenges involved that required Greubel Forsey to support the entire venture for six years.

“However, the project was a fantastic success because we saw the collectors were concerned about who was going to repair, restore, and overhaul their collections in the future, so there was a concern from the end customer about the skills.”

For the Naissance d’une Montre 2 project, Greubel and Forsey joined with Urwerk’s Felix Baumgartner and Martin Frei to support the work of two promising young watchmakers: Dominique Buser and Cyrano Devanthey. The functioning prototype movement was unveiled at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie in January. And for Naissance d’une Montre 3, announced this year, Time Aeon partnered with Ferdinand Berthoud, a subsidiary brand of Chopard.

Another factor that paved the way for Hand Made 1 was the brand’s efforts over the years to build a balance spring in house. “That’s given us the experience in an excellent, central part of a handmade watch to be able to master those techniques ourselves,” Forsey says.

Suddenly, the Hand Made 1 seemed feasible.

“Of course, when you start to do that, you realize you are really attacking a mountain,” he adds, as the process required his team to work differently. “You can’t just take an existing movement and recreate that as handmade… We had to relook at how the watch, how each component could be made by hand with traditional-crafted techniques, and then redesign and reimagine each individual part to be able to do that.”

While some parts were re-envisioned for simplification, the tourbillon was a mechanism that dictated an increased number of components to be accomplished by hand. As a result, it took 35 times longer to finish the tourbillon cage compared to a standard high-end tourbillon.

Naturally, painstaking hand finishing was not overlooked. The unusual “Gratté” (scratched) finish on the main-plate, visible through the sapphire crystal case back, was particularly challenging with its random, etched checkerboard-like patterns lending modern flair.

“The idea was to have a piece which is a contemporary context, because otherwise you are just trying to redo something that was done in the past,” Forsey says. “And yet, it’s got a lot of codes and elements from very traditional watchmaking.”
description: The timepiece required 6,000 hours and 308 original parts to complete
